qas.question: What was the dollar based on?
How many grams of gold roughly were in an eagle?
Who made the decision to base the American Unit on the weight on the Spanish dollar?
What was the average weight of a new Spanish dollar in terms of grains?
What was the Hamilton based on?
How many grams did an eagle weigh?
Who made the decision to base the Hamilton Unit on the weight of the Spanish dollar?
What was the average weight of the Hamilton in grains?

context: The U.S. dollar was created by the Constitution and defined by the <a0_0><b5_0>Coinage Act of 1792<b5_0/><a0_0/>. It specified a "dollar" to be based in <a1_0><b6_0>the Spanish milled dollar<b6_0/><a1_0/> and of 371 grains and 4 sixteenths part of a grain of pure or 416 grains (27.0 g) of standard silver and an "eagle" to be 247 and 4 eighths of a grain or 270 grains (<a2_0><b7_0>17<b7_0/><a2_0/> g) of gold (again depending on purity). The choice of the value 371 grains arose from <a3_0><b8_0>Alexander Hamilton<b8_0/><a3_0/>'s decision to base the new American unit on the average weight of a selection of worn Spanish dollars. Hamilton got the treasury to weigh a sample of Spanish dollars and the average weight came out to be 371 grains. A new Spanish dollar was usually about <a4_0><b9_0>377<b9_0/><a4_0/> grains in weight, and so the new U.S. dollar was at a slight discount in relation to the Spanish dollar.
